results.title: Hovercraft
results.creator_credit: John Read, Brith Broadcasting Corporation and Peter Bennet Stone
results.brief_description: The story of Christopher Cockerell and of his invention, the Hovercraft. Tells how he developed the principle while running a small boatyard on the Norfolk Broads and how after many attempts the idea was adapted by industry. Describes the construction and operation of the latest British Hovercraft made by four different firms, and a high speed journey along the coast of the Isle of Wight.

results.title: Hoverbug
results.creator_credit: George H. Brown, Fanfare Films and Jan Darnley-Smith
results.brief_description: Young Dick and Jenny Brewster are trying to build a small hovercraft to enter into a race. Mr Watts, an eccentric inventor, offers his help. Charley Guthridge and his mate Sidney plot to prevent Dick and Jenny from building their home-made hovercraft. On the day of the big race, Dick and Jenny stuggle to take the lead and beat their opponents. Stars Jill Riddick; John Trayhorn; Francis Attard; Gary Cann; Arthur Howard; Michael Balfour; Jan Butlin; Peter Myers; Cardew Robinson; Michael Segal; Harold Goodwin; Marianne Stone; and Janet Waldron.

results.title: Housing in Scotland
results.creator_credit: Merlin Films, Great Britain. Ministry of Information and Gilbert Gunn
results.brief_description: Recalls Scotland’s efforts in pioneering housing schemes and gives details of the immediate postwar plans for building. Looks at temporary structures, to meet emergency needs; two-family dwellings which can later be converted into single dwellings; and permanent modern homes. Although the film deals with a serious subject, its approach is occasionaly light and humourous.

results.title: Houses in the town
results.brief_description: Analyses the problems and practices of architects responsible for the design of new towns and “neighbourhoods” in Britain. A lecturer on town and country planning discusses the problem of density, illustrated by views of old, over-crowded tenements and newer, insufficiently compact buildings. An architect suggests how houses may be designed to conform to the character of the environment, how variety may be obtained in shapes, and useful and aesthetically pleasing spaces created. His points are made with the aid of models and actual scenes.

results.title: Houses in history
results.creator_credit: Paul Rotha, Seven-League Unit and H.M. Nieter
results.brief_description: The different kinds of material used for building in the British Isles and their influence on construction are studied, with a brief survey of the development of houses in England from the 13th century until today.

results.title: Houses have history
results.creator_credit: George McQuilkin, Churchill Films and Paul Fillinger
results.brief_description: Children look at old buildings and their features in and around San Francisco/Sacramento, USA. Examines how a neighbourhood has changed and the growing interest in preserving and renovating old buildings. Suitable for upper primary and lower secondary levels.

results.title: Houses Fit for People
results.brief_description:
Episode number 8 of Series “Architecture at the Crossroads Series”.
Part Eight of a series which examines the main themes in world architecture today. The series looks at the work of architects who are at the centre of the current debate, and introduces some younger architects who are beginning to make a name for themselves. Part Eight deals with domestic housing. Most famous architects are concerned with commercial and institutional architecture. Ordinary people have to live in “junk” but there are signs that housing design is undergoing a change for the better. In the suburbs of Paris and London, a more humane architecture is beginning to emerge which challenges the monotony of the “new town” ideal.

results.title: Housekeeping
results.creator_credit: Robert F. Colesberry, Columbia Pictures and Bill Forsyth
results.brief_description: Abandoned early in life, Ruth and Lucille have been raised by various relatives - now it’s Aunt Sylvie’s (Christine Lahti) turn. But Aunt Sylvie isn’t like their other relatives, she used to be a hobo and can’t seem to change her eccentric ways. She takes midday naps on park benches and wears an overcoat lined with old newspapers. Sylvie may be embarrassing, but she’s like a breath of fresh air to the two girls. Can Lucille and Ruth cope with Sylvie, and can Sylvie cope with the real responsibility of a family? This is a beautiful story of quirky relationships, loneliness, and the bonding of kindred spirits. Based on the book by Marilynne Robinson.

results.title: Houseboat
results.creator_credit: Jack Rose, Paramount Pictures and Melville Shavelson
results.brief_description: Poor little rich-girl ends up being the governess to a widower and his three children aboard an old houseboat. Sophia Loren and Cary Grant steam up the screen in this classic romantic comedy, complete with luscious colour and ‘VistaVision’ widescreen presentation from 1950s cinema. Resplendent in divine gowns designed by Edith Head, Sophia Loren learns about life and love with a few song and dance routines along the way. The three lead children are also delightful in this witty and entertaining film. Cast includes Martha Hyer and Harry Guardino. Winner of two Academy Awards for Best Song and Best Screenplay, written by Melville Shavelson and Jack Rose.
